title: Media and Communication Studies
description: Specialized vocabulary for analyzing media, communication, and public discourse

items.definition: False information deliberately created and spread to deceive
items.example: The report detailed how disinformation campaigns targeted voters in swing states.

items.definition: A particular way of presenting a story or series of events; a framing of information
items.example: The competing narratives about the crisis shaped public perception differently.

items.definition: Division into sharply contrasting groups with opposing views
items.example: Political polarization has made bipartisan cooperation increasingly difficult.

items.definition: The art of persuasive speaking or writing; language designed to persuade
items.example: The politician's rhetoric appealed to fears rather than facts.

items.definition: The way an issue is presented, which influences how it is understood
items.example: The framing of immigration as a security issue rather than an economic one shifted the debate.

items.definition: The tendency of content to spread rapidly through online sharing
items.example: The video's virality meant it reached millions before any fact-checking occurred.

items.definition: An environment where one encounters only opinions similar to one's own
items.example: Social media algorithms can create echo chambers that reinforce existing beliefs.
collocations: break out of the echo chamber

items.definition: The quality of being trusted and believed; reliability of a source
items.example: The journalist's credibility was enhanced by her track record of accurate reporting.
